text:
Hi all, I’m having some trouble with my Julia workflow, and I’d love some recommendations. This question has some Julia and some VSCode components (I’m new to both). Not sure if that’s appropriate for this channel.
First, my compile times are really long, like order of minutes. I’m running some simple training scripts  for Flux in the VSCode Julia REPL, that depend on ~5 small custom modules. I know precompilation is a major focus of the upcoming release, but are there other ways to mitigate this startup time? For instance, is there a way to have VSCode continuously compile my code (this would also maybe help with syntax highlighting)? I’ve tried using Revise, but I found that the state in my repl quickly got confusing, and I ended up just using `include(<script.jl>)`  anyway. In a related point, it looks like maybe there isn’t a way to <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/how-to-clear-variables-and-or-whole-work-space/10149|reset the state of the REPL> without restarting, which then necessitates a recompile. I haven’t really gotten the Debugger to work (it often just hangs), but I didn’t spend much time looking into it. What workflows do you all use?

attachments.title: How to clear variables and/or whole work space
attachments.text: hello ,i’m a newcomer. i use Atom as my IDE for julia . How to clear the information in REPL and the variables that i do not need in the work space
attachments.fallback: JuliaLang: How to clear variables and/or whole work space

text: Yeah as I said I was using Revise for awhile, but ended up moving away from it. Maybe I was using it wrong? I think the issue was that I was ending up in states that surprised me (like code would update but variables would not). Maybe I need to try again

text: What do you mean “everything in functions”? Does that mean no modules?

elements.text: What do you mean “everything in functions”? Does that mean no modules?
